text: The quick brown fox jumps over the lazy dog. This is a sample training example for fine-tuning language models.
Machine learning is a subset of artificial intelligence that focuses on algorithms and statistical models.
Natural language processing enables computers to understand, interpret, and generate human language.
Deep learning uses neural networks with multiple layers to model complex patterns in data.
Transfer learning allows models to leverage knowledge from pre-trained models for new tasks.
Fine-tuning adapts pre-trained models to specific domains or tasks with additional training data.
LoRA (Low-Rank Adaptation) is an efficient method for fine-tuning large language models.
The transformer architecture revolutionized natural language processing with attention mechanisms.
Attention is all you need - the title of the seminal paper that introduced transformers.
Self-attention allows models to focus on different parts of the input sequence when processing each token.
Gradient descent is an optimization algorithm used to minimize loss functions in machine learning.
Backpropagation is a method for calculating gradients in neural networks.
Regularization techniques help prevent overfitting in machine learning models.
Cross-validation is a technique for assessing how well a model will generalize to new data.
Hyperparameter tuning is the process of finding optimal values for model parameters.
Data preprocessing involves cleaning and transforming raw data for machine learning.
Feature engineering is the process of creating new features from existing data.
Model evaluation metrics help assess the performance of machine learning models.
Ensemble methods combine multiple models to improve prediction accuracy.
Neural networks are computational models inspired by biological neural networks.
